Award.AbstractNarration:
Doctoral Dissertation Research: Explaining the Valuation of Non-Standard Goods in the Global Economy

Sustainable production and consumption have become a focus of policy-making as growing scientific evidence points to the possibility that current economic practices are depleting valuable resources on a broad scale. Recycling and prevention of waste through reuse are key aspects of these policies, yet little is known about how these waste management measures are practiced, especially as goods for reuse are exported from one country to another. This dissertation focuses on the global value chain for used clothing to understand what happens to discarded items that are transformed from waste and diverted from landfill by being given value. Drawing from economic sociology and waste studies, this project seeks to provide an account of valuation of these waste flows. This dissertation will develop a theory of valuation that can account for cases in which goods are highly unstandardized. Existing sociological explanations of valuation cannot account for how value is created along the global value chain of used clothing, where goods are highly variable and supply is unpredictable. Understanding how waste is transformed into a commodity is important to countries seeking to develop waste management policies that are nationally and globally effective and sustainable.

This study is a multi-sited, mixed-methods study that traces the value chain of used clothing from the United Kingdom to Poland. The central empirical question asks how value is created along the global value chain of used clothing. This dissertation relies on a comparison of how used clothing market actors at different points along the global value chain of used clothing make decisions about value and waste. Data will include in-depth, semi-structured interviews with actors involved in the collection, sorting, processing, exporting, importing, or selling of used clothing in the UK and Poland. Interviews will be informed and supplemented by observation and participant observation in sites at each of six analytically-identified stages along the value chain of used clothing between the UK and Poland. Field notes, interview transcripts, and photographs will be qualitatively coded. Quantitative data regarding amounts and percentages of clothing sold/discarded will come from a structured component of interviews and supplemented by existing industry data. These data, as well as existing business register data, will be analyzed using tabular and multivariate analysis to help explain variations found in the qualitative data and to assess the generalizability of the qualitative findings. This research contributes both to economic sociology and to recycling and waste policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This dissertation research investigated the production of value for used clothing, one of the many types of post-consumer used goods that travel around the world in value chains. A multi-sited ethnographic study tracked the paths of used clothing within and between the United Kingdom and Poland. 38 qualitative, in-depth, semi-structured interviews were conducted with actors involved in the collection, sorting, processing, exporting, importing, sale, management, and/or disposal of used textiles and/or clothing in the UK and Poland. Observation and participant observation were conducted over the course of five months in the UK in textile warehouses (collection, sorting, wholesale, and export) and charity shops (collection, sorting, retail), and over the course of six months in Poland in textile warehouses (import, sorting, wholesale, export), and used clothing shops (sorting, retail). These sites were formal and informal settings, including charity shops, recycling centers, community swap meets, and textile recycling warehouses. The research also included interviews with actors involved in the formalization of the used clothing trade, including those who developed programs to quantify and track flows of textiles diverted from landfill, and industry spokespeople.

 

This research identified key actors and organizations involved in the trade of used clothing in the UK and Poland, as well as the ways in which these actors and organizations are connected and how they influence each others’ operations, especially value production strategies/practices (construction of supply and qualification of goods) and waste production/avoidance strategies/practices. There are two main ways in which textile collectors at the top of a value chain control the supply of material from which they will extract value. 1. Textile collectors compete with each other for supply—for the right to acquire cast-off clothing and textiles. 2. Textile collectors attempt to influence what is or is not collected through the enforcement of rules or through more subtle cues (encouragement of certain practices). The research found that qualification strategies—ways in which the value and qualities of used clothing was demonstrated—were also developed in relationships between actors and organizations, especially with regard to the way that pricing systems and logistical/organizational capacities allowed actors to present used clothing in ways that allow it to move onwards, while creating value for their organizations. This research shows that waste is socially created in at least three ways. 1. The infrastructures and organizations which make it possible to discard certain materials and create waste flows need to have a level of legitimacy associated with them. 2. What does or does not become waste is contingent upon modes of value production employed. 3. Waste is quantified and made visible to policymakers and industry actors by technologies, accounting systems, and reporting procedures.

 

The data collected in the course of this project indicate that there is a relation between the production of value and the production of waste along the value chain for used clothing. The main hypothesis that when goods are unstandardized, valuation processes are contingent upon wasting processes that allow sellers to standardize goods was confirmed. Additionally, this research found that the original conception of the value chain did not account for several factors: the role of regulatory authorities (local, national, and supra-national waste management bodies and/or authorities) in determining how used clothing is handled and who has access, the role of social trust in value production, and the more diverse sites and paths along which used clothing travels in addition to the global value chain. Finally, there are two further outcomes that arose from the conducted research. First, this project shows at a micro level some of the mechanisms necessary for the formalization of a global value chain. Second, this research is itself part of a process of formalization, as it singles out a single type of economic entity to explain from a larger ecology of flows and types of exchange. This project describes valuation as a social, material, and logistical process, thus contributing to the study of valuation processes in anthropology, Science and Technology studies, and an interdisciplinary literature on waste.

 

In terms of broader impact, the project generates new empirical knowledge about the outcomes of reuse initiatives as these are increasingly a part of official economic planning (at multiple levels, including regional, national, inter- or intra-national, and global).
